2 factor authentication.definition: An extra layer of security used to make sure that people trying to gain access to an online account are who they say they are.

2 factor authentications.definition: An extra layer of security used to make sure that people trying to gain access to an online account are who they say they are.

51% attack.definition: An attack on blockchain consensus by controlling over 51% of the block producing power on the network.

51% attacks.definition: An attack on blockchain consensus by controlling over 51% of the block producing power on the network.

adresse.definition: Identifiant public unique d'une entité sur une blockchain.

addresss.definition: Identifiant public unique d'une entité sur une blockchain.

aggregator.definition: Tool that combines multiple sources, to offer competitive options.

aggregators.definition: Tool that combines multiple sources, to offer competitive options.

airdrop.definition: A free distribution of crypto assets to users.

airdrops.definition: A free distribution of crypto assets to users.

allowance.definition: Allows an entity, usually a smart contract, the right to use a specified amount of your tokens in a transaction.

allowances.definition: Allows an entity, usually a smart contract, the right to use a specified amount of your tokens in a transaction.

alternative layer 1.definition: Layer 1 blockchains other than Ethereum and Bitcoin.

alternative layer 1s.definition: Layer 1 blockchains other than Ethereum and Bitcoin.

amm.definition: (Automated Market Maker) A trade matchmaking system, based on a public algorithm.

amms.definition: (Automated Market Maker) A trade matchmaking system, based on a public algorithm.

asynchrone.definition: Communication entre plusieurs collaborateurs, où les participants n'ont pas besoin d'être présents au moment de l'envoi du message.

asynchronouss.definition: Communication entre plusieurs collaborateurs, où les participants n'ont pas besoin d'être présents au moment de l'envoi du message.

bet.definition: Risking money in exchange for greater rewards.

bets.definition: Risking money in exchange for greater rewards.

block.definition: A group of transactions on the blockchain.

blocks.definition: A group of transactions on the blockchain.

block explorer.definition: Search and exploration tool for blockchain data.

block explorers.definition: Search and exploration tool for blockchain data.

block hash.definition: The unique identifier for each block file. Each new block refers to the block hash of the previous block to form the single-file connected blockchain.

block hashs.definition: The unique identifier for each block file. Each new block refers to the block hash of the previous block to form the single-file connected blockchain.

producteur de blocs.definition: L'utilisateur dont le matériel est choisi pour vérifier les transactions d'un bloc et commencer le bloc suivant sur la plupart des blockchains à preuve d'enjeu [Proof-of-Stake].

producteurs de blocs.definition: L'utilisateur dont le matériel est choisi pour vérifier les transactions d'un bloc et commencer le bloc suivant sur la plupart des blockchains à preuve d'enjeu [Proof-of-Stake].

block reward.definition: The amount of a blockchain’s native asset given to the proposer of a new valid block.

block rewards.definition: The amount of a blockchain’s native asset given to the proposer of a new valid block.

blockchain.definition: A shared, unchangeable database, or ledger, of recorded transactions.

blockchains.definition: A shared, unchangeable database, or ledger, of recorded transactions.

blockchain architecture.definition: The structures for how data is stored in blockchain technology.

blockchain architectures.definition: The structures for how data is stored in blockchain technology.

blockchain trilemma.definition: The problem describing the need for all 3 blockchain qualities: Security, Scalability, and Decentralization.

blockchain trilemmas.definition: The problem describing the need for all 3 blockchain qualities: Security, Scalability, and Decentralization.

espace de blocs.definition: La quantité d'espace sur une blockchain qui peut être utilisée pour stocker des informations et exécuter du code. La quantité d'"espace" à l'intérieur d'un (ou d'une série de) bloc(s).

espace de bloc.definition: La quantité d'espace sur une blockchain qui peut être utilisée pour stocker des informations et exécuter du code. La quantité d'"espace" à l'intérieur d'un (ou d'une série de) bloc(s).

borrower.definition: Willing to pay interest to lenders in order to borrow assets.

borrowers.definition: Willing to pay interest to lenders in order to borrow assets.

bridge.definition: Connection that allows two different blockchain networks to communicate with each other and exchange assets.

bridges.definition: Connection that allows two different blockchain networks to communicate with each other and exchange assets.

censorship-resistant.definition: No government or company has control to determine what is or is not allowed.

censorship-resistants.definition: No government or company has control to determine what is or is not allowed.

échange centralisé.definition: (Échange Centralisé) Plateforme qui coordonne les échanges de crypto-monnaies contre rémunération, à l'instar d'une bourse.

échanges centralisés.definition: (Échange Centralisé) Plateforme qui coordonne les échanges de crypto-monnaies contre rémunération, à l'instar d'une bourse.

cex.definition: (Échange Centralisé) Plateforme qui coordonne les échanges de crypto-monnaies contre rémunération, à l'instar d'une bourse.

cexs.definition: (Échange Centralisé) Plateforme qui coordonne les échanges de crypto-monnaies contre rémunération, à l'instar d'une bourse.

chain.definition: Binds blocks of data together to form a database which cannot be altered or changed.

chains.definition: Binds blocks of data together to form a database which cannot be altered or changed.

coin.definition: The native asset of a blockchain mostly used as a form of currency to facilitate transactions on the network.

coins.definition: The native asset of a blockchain mostly used as a form of currency to facilitate transactions on the network.

cold wallet.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that is stored on offline hardware.

cold wallets.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that is stored on offline hardware.

collateral.definition: A borrower's pledge of specific asset(s) to a lender, to secure repayment of a loan.

collaterals.definition: A borrower's pledge of specific asset(s) to a lender, to secure repayment of a loan.

consensus.definition: Agreement, trust, and security across a decentralized computer network like blockchains.

consensuss.definition: Agreement, trust, and security across a decentralized computer network like blockchains.

counterparty risk.definition: The risk that another party may not fulfil its part in an agreement.

counterparty risks.definition: The risk that another party may not fulfil its part in an agreement.

custodial wallet.definition: With a custodial wallet, another party controls the private keys, thus controlling access to your crypto assets.

custodial wallets.definition: With a custodial wallet, another party controls the private keys, thus controlling access to your crypto assets.

dao.definition: (Organisation Autonome Décentralisée) Une structure organisationnelle qui utilise la technologie blockchain pour automatiser le vote et la gestion.

daos.definition: (Organisation Autonome Décentralisée) Une structure organisationnelle qui utilise la technologie blockchain pour automatiser le vote et la gestion.

dapp.definition: Une application décentralisée qui se connecte à des réseaux et protocoles décentralisés.

dapps.definition: Une application décentralisée qui se connecte à des réseaux et protocoles décentralisés.

decentralization.definition: Principle that no single authority or entity should control the blockchain data.

decentralizations.definition: Principle that no single authority or entity should control the blockchain data.

decentralized.definition: No single authority or entity controls the data.

decentralizeds.definition: No single authority or entity controls the data.

èchange décentralisé.definition: (Échange Décentralisé) Un protocole qui facilite les échanges sans nécessiter d'intermédiaires de confiance.

échanges décentralisés.definition: (Échange Décentralisé) Un protocole qui facilite les échanges sans nécessiter d'intermédiaires de confiance.

decentralized finance.definition: (DeFi) A set of self-custody finance tools, hosted on a blockchain.

decentralized finances.definition: (DeFi) A set of self-custody finance tools, hosted on a blockchain.

defi.definition: (Decentralized Finance) A set of self-custody finance tools, hosted on a blockchain.

defis.definition: (Decentralized Finance) A set of self-custody finance tools, hosted on a blockchain.

déléguer.definition: Donner une responsabilité spécifique à une autre personne, par exemple la délégation d'un pouvoir de vote.

delegates.definition: Donner une responsabilité spécifique à une autre personne, par exemple la délégation d'un pouvoir de vote.

délégation.definition: Donner une responsabilité spécifique à une autre personne, par exemple la délégation d'un pouvoir de vote.

delegations.definition: Donner une responsabilité spécifique à une autre personne, par exemple la délégation d'un pouvoir de vote.

dex.definition: Échange décentralisé : Un protocole qui facilite les échanges sans nécessiter d'intermédiaires de confiance.

dexs.definition: Échange décentralisé : Un protocole qui facilite les échanges sans nécessiter d'intermédiaires de confiance.

agrégateur d'échange décentralisé.definition: Protocol that combines DEX liquidity from multiple sources in one interface.

dex aggregators.definition: Protocol that combines DEX liquidity from multiple sources in one interface.

digital signature.definition: The unique identifier for each user that serves the function of personal stamps or physical signatures in the digital space.

digital signatures.definition: The unique identifier for each user that serves the function of personal stamps or physical signatures in the digital space.

earn.definition: Contributing value in exchange for rewards ; money verb on the skill cube.

earns.definition: Contributing value in exchange for rewards ; money verb on the skill cube.

epoch.definition: The time taken for a specific number of blocks to be included on any particular blockchain.

epochs.definition: The time taken for a specific number of blocks to be included on any particular blockchain.

erc-20.definition: Une norme pour les jetons fongibles transférables sur Ethereum. Ces jetons sont divisibles et non uniques.

erc-20s.definition: Une norme pour les jetons fongibles transférables sur Ethereum. Ces jetons sont divisibles et non uniques.

erc-721.definition: Une norme pour les jetons non fongibles sur Ethereum. Ces jetons ont un identifiant numérique unique et ne peuvent pas être copiés, substitués ou divisés.

erc-721s.definition: Une norme pour les jetons non fongibles sur Ethereum. Ces jetons ont un identifiant numérique unique et ne peuvent pas être copiés, substitués ou divisés.

ethereum virtual machine.definition: The Ethereum Virtual Machine or EVM is a piece of software that executes smart contracts and computes the state of the Ethereum network.

ethereum virtual machines.definition: The Ethereum Virtual Machine or EVM is a piece of software that executes smart contracts and computes the state of the Ethereum network.

fomo.definition: (Fear Of Missing Out) Anxiety or apprehension about not being included in something.

fomos.definition: (Fear Of Missing Out) Anxiety or apprehension about not being included in something.

forker.definition: Il s'agit d'un changement radical dans un réseau de blockchain qui donne lieu à deux branches, l'une suivant le protocole précédent et l'autre un nouveau protocole.

forks.definition: Il s'agit d'un changement radical dans un réseau de blockchain qui donne lieu à deux branches, l'une suivant le protocole précédent et l'autre un nouveau protocole.

fraud proof.definition: Evidence that a transaction is invalid and that fraud has occurred.

fraud proofs.definition: Evidence that a transaction is invalid and that fraud has occurred.

gasless transactions.definition: A transaction that pays gas using some of the token to be traded rather than the native coin of the blockchain network.

gasless transactionss.definition: A transaction that pays gas using some of the token to be traded rather than the native coin of the blockchain network.

gwei.definition: A unit used on Ethereum blockchain, equivalent to 0.000000001 ETH (one billionth), used commonly to describe gas prices.

gweis.definition: A unit used on Ethereum blockchain, equivalent to 0.000000001 ETH (one billionth), used commonly to describe gas prices.

hardware wallet.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that stores private keys offline in a physical hardware device.

hardware wallets.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that stores private keys offline in a physical hardware device.

hashing function.definition: A function that is easy to calculate in one direction only, making it nearly impossible to reverse engineer the inputs and functionally guaranteeing unique outputs for a given input.

hashing functions.definition: A function that is easy to calculate in one direction only, making it nearly impossible to reverse engineer the inputs and functionally guaranteeing unique outputs for a given input.

hodl.definition: (Hold On for Dear Life) Crypto slang for not selling crypto no matter what the market conditions are.

hodls.definition: (Hold On for Dear Life) Crypto slang for not selling crypto no matter what the market conditions are.

hot wallet.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that is perpetually connected to the internet.

hot wallets.definition: A type of self-custody wallet that is perpetually connected to the internet.

intermediary token.definition: A token that is part of the middle of a trade route, not the starting or ending token.

intermediary tokens.definition: A token that is part of the middle of a trade route, not the starting or ending token.

invest.definition: The act of buying a coin/token that uses DeFi technology.

invests.definition: The act of buying a coin/token that uses DeFi technology.

l1.definition: Layer 1 refers to a base network such as Bitcoin or Ethereum.

l1s.definition: Layer 1 refers to a base network such as Bitcoin or Ethereum.

l2.definition: Une blockchain de Couche 2 [L2/Layer2] étend la scalabilité d'Ethereum tout en héritant de la sécurité d'Ethereum.

l2s.definition: Une blockchain de Couche 2 [L2/Layer2] étend la scalabilité d'Ethereum tout en héritant de la sécurité d'Ethereum.

layer 1.definition: Layer 1 refers to a base network such as Bitcoin or Ethereum.

layer 1s.definition: Layer 1 refers to a base network such as Bitcoin or Ethereum.

couche 2.definition: Une blockchain de Couche 2 [L2/Layer2] étend la scalabilité d'Ethereum tout en héritant de la sécurité d'Ethereum.

layer 2s.definition: Une blockchain de Couche 2 [L2/Layer2] étend la scalabilité d'Ethereum tout en héritant de la sécurité d'Ethereum.

ledger.definition: The record of all transactions that have ever occurred.

ledgers.definition: The record of all transactions that have ever occurred.

liquidity.definition: The quantity of a token available for trading.

liquiditys.definition: The quantity of a token available for trading.

liquidity pool.definition: A communal vault of tokens that facilitates permissionless token swaps.

liquidity pools.definition: A communal vault of tokens that facilitates permissionless token swaps.

lp.definition: (Liquidity Provider) Blockchain users who loan their tokens to protocols in exchange for a share in fees.

lps.definition: (Liquidity Provider) Blockchain users who loan their tokens to protocols in exchange for a share in fees.

market cap.definition: The total value of a given token, or market sector.

market caps.definition: The total value of a given token, or market sector.

meta-aggregator.definition: A tool that brings together other aggregators into an extra overview layer.

meta-aggregators.definition: A tool that brings together other aggregators into an extra overview layer.

mev.definition: Maximal extractible value - value extracted by ordering transactions within blocks.

mevs.definition: Maximal extractible value - value extracted by ordering transactions within blocks.

gouvernance du réseau.definition: Le processus par lequel une communauté décentralisée parvient à un accord sur les caractéristiques du réseau et ses mises à jour.

network governances.definition: Le processus par lequel une communauté décentralisée parvient à un accord sur les caractéristiques du réseau et ses mises à jour.

nft.definition: (Non-fungible Token) A token with a unique ID that cannot be replicated, as compared to a fungible token like Ether that has no unique identifier.

nfts.definition: (Non-fungible Token) A token with a unique ID that cannot be replicated, as compared to a fungible token like Ether that has no unique identifier.

gouvernance onchain.definition: Le système automatisé qui permet de modifier la structure d'une blockchain.

onchain governances.definition: Le système automatisé qui permet de modifier la structure d'une blockchain.

open source.definition: Logiciel libre dont le code source peut être consulté, modifié et amélioré par tout un chacun.

open sources.definition: Logiciel libre dont le code source peut être consulté, modifié et amélioré par tout un chacun.

optimistic rollup.definition: A layer 2 rollup scaling solution that optimistically assumes all transactions in its “rolled up” transaction are valid until they are proven false by a fraud proof.

optimistic rollups.definition: A layer 2 rollup scaling solution that optimistically assumes all transactions in its “rolled up” transaction are valid until they are proven false by a fraud proof.

otc.definition: (Over the Counter) Trades made directly with private entities.

otcs.definition: (Over the Counter) Trades made directly with private entities.

over the counter.definition: (OTC) Trades made directly with private entities.

over the counters.definition: (OTC) Trades made directly with private entities.

payment channel.definition: Allows two parties to transact multiple times without the need for each transaction to be recorded on the blockchain.

payment channels.definition: Allows two parties to transact multiple times without the need for each transaction to be recorded on the blockchain.

peer-to-peer.definition: A transaction between two parties that does not require a middleman or controlling entity.

peer-to-peers.definition: A transaction between two parties that does not require a middleman or controlling entity.

peg.definition: Method of maintaining value equivalence between two or more assets.

pegs.definition: Method of maintaining value equivalence between two or more assets.

permissionless.definition: Not requiring the permission of any entity.

permissionlesss.definition: Not requiring the permission of any entity.

phishing.definition: A type of social engineering attack where the attacker poses as a trusted person or organization to trick victims into sharing sensitive information or sending them money.

phishings.definition: A type of social engineering attack where the attacker poses as a trusted person or organization to trick victims into sharing sensitive information or sending them money.

poap.definition: A POAP (Proof of Attendance Protocol) is a badge that keeps a reliable record of life experiences in your wallet, like for example successfully completing a lesson.

poaps.definition: A POAP (Proof of Attendance Protocol) is a badge that keeps a reliable record of life experiences in your wallet, like for example successfully completing a lesson.

price impact.definition: The amount prices on a DEX change due to the trade size.

price impacts.definition: The amount prices on a DEX change due to the trade size.

private key.definition: A private key allows access to your wallet in order for you to send crypto assets to other address.

private keys.definition: A private key allows access to your wallet in order for you to send crypto assets to other address.

proof of stake.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that randomly choose a block producer based on a stake each entity has locked into the protocol.

proof of stakes.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that randomly choose a block producer based on a stake each entity has locked into the protocol.

proof of work.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that rely on “work” done by miners competing to create valid blocks by proposing blocks and seeing if each one has a valid hash.

proof of works.definition: Blockchain Consensus algorithms that rely on “work” done by miners competing to create valid blocks by proposing blocks and seeing if each one has a valid hash.

public.definition: Public blockchains allow anyone to view the blockchain ledger.

publics.definition: Public blockchains allow anyone to view the blockchain ledger.

bien public.definition: Un bien public est une marchandise ou un service qui est disponible pour tous les membres de la société.

biens publics.definition: Un bien public est une marchandise ou un service qui est disponible pour tous les membres de la société.

public key.definition: A public key is your address. It gives others a point of reference to send crypto assets to you.

public keys.definition: A public key is your address. It gives others a point of reference to send crypto assets to you.

recovery phrase.definition: A recovery phrase is a list of 12 to 24 words which is used to generate your wallet's public key and private key.

recovery phrases.definition: A recovery phrase is a list of 12 to 24 words which is used to generate your wallet's public key and private key.

retropgf.definition: (Financement Rétroactif des Biens Publics) Mécanisme de financement de projets, basé sur leur impact historique.

retropgfs.definition: (Financement Rétroactif des Biens Publics) Mécanisme de financement de projets, basé sur leur impact historique.

rollup.definition: A layer-2 scaling solution that allows for processing a high number of off-chain transactions and aggregating them in a single, larger on-chain transaction, increasing transaction throughput and lowering costs.

rollups.definition: A layer-2 scaling solution that allows for processing a high number of off-chain transactions and aggregating them in a single, larger on-chain transaction, increasing transaction throughput and lowering costs.

sandwich attack.definition: A hidden cost for users due to ordering of transactions by block producers.

sandwich attacks.definition: A hidden cost for users due to ordering of transactions by block producers.

scalability.definition: A blockchain’s capability to handle a growing amount of work, transactions, and usage with minimal disruption for users.

scalabilitys.definition: A blockchain’s capability to handle a growing amount of work, transactions, and usage with minimal disruption for users.

scam-token.definition: A cryptocurrency token that is launched for the sole purpose of stealing investor funds.

scam-tokens.definition: A cryptocurrency token that is launched for the sole purpose of stealing investor funds.

security.definition: Ability of a blockchain to withstand hacking attempts, code exploits, and economic exploits among other attacks, and continue to function as normal.

securitys.definition: Ability of a blockchain to withstand hacking attempts, code exploits, and economic exploits among other attacks, and continue to function as normal.

seed phrase.definition: Group of random words generated by a wallet on setup, they act as the master key to ALL accounts controlled by that wallet. NEVER SHARE YOUR SEED PHRASE WITH ANYONE FOR ANY REASON.

seed phrases.definition: Group of random words generated by a wallet on setup, they act as the master key to ALL accounts controlled by that wallet. NEVER SHARE YOUR SEED PHRASE WITH ANYONE FOR ANY REASON.

self-custody wallet.definition: (AKA: Non-custodial wallet) With a self-custody wallet, you have sole control of your private keys, which in turn control your crypto assets.

self-custody wallets.definition: (AKA: Non-custodial wallet) With a self-custody wallet, you have sole control of your private keys, which in turn control your crypto assets.

settlement layer.definition: The “lowest” level of a blockchain that records the details of asset exchange from finalized transactions. Mainnet Ethereum is the settlement layer for Ethereum layer 2 scaling solutions.

settlement layers.definition: The “lowest” level of a blockchain that records the details of asset exchange from finalized transactions. Mainnet Ethereum is the settlement layer for Ethereum layer 2 scaling solutions.

settlement time.definition: The time need for a transaction to be confirmed.

settlement times.definition: The time need for a transaction to be confirmed.

sharding.definition: The process of splitting a single blockchain into multiple chains that all run together in parallel to increase scalability.

shardings.definition: The process of splitting a single blockchain into multiple chains that all run together in parallel to increase scalability.

sidechain.definition: A mechanism that allows for the transfer of assets and transactions from a main blockchain to a separate, parallel blockchain (sidechain).

sidechains.definition: A mechanism that allows for the transfer of assets and transactions from a main blockchain to a separate, parallel blockchain (sidechain).

slippage.definition: A change in buy price that helps your trade to execute.

slippages.definition: A change in buy price that helps your trade to execute.

slippage tolerance.definition: How much can prices change before your trade executes.

slippage tolerances.definition: How much can prices change before your trade executes.

smart contract.definition: Computerized code that execute terms of a contract automatically.

smart contracts.definition: Computerized code that execute terms of a contract automatically.

social engineering.definition: Manipulating someone into sharing sensitive or confidential information such as passwords or seed phrases.

social engineerings.definition: Manipulating someone into sharing sensitive or confidential information such as passwords or seed phrases.

spend.definition: Using your crypto assets to pay for goods or services.

spends.definition: Using your crypto assets to pay for goods or services.

stake.definition: The amount of a financial asset locked into a cryptocurrency protocol. It represents someone’s financial commitment to the protocol, their “skin in the game”.

stakes.definition: The amount of a financial asset locked into a cryptocurrency protocol. It represents someone’s financial commitment to the protocol, their “skin in the game”.

staking.definition: The temporary commitment of a portion of your crypto into a smart contract for a specified amount of time in exchange for earning interest ("rewards").

stakings.definition: The temporary commitment of a portion of your crypto into a smart contract for a specified amount of time in exchange for earning interest ("rewards").

swap.definition: A trade from one token to another.

swaps.definition: A trade from one token to another.

token.definition: Units that can stand for assets or deeds that are built on an existing blockchain.

tokens.definition: Units that can stand for assets or deeds that are built on an existing blockchain.

token allowance.definition: An agreement between a wallet and smart contract, allowing limited or unlimited access to a specific token.

token allowances.definition: An agreement between a wallet and smart contract, allowing limited or unlimited access to a specific token.

distribution de jetons.definition: La manière dont les jetons sont répartis entre les différents groupes de parties prenantes.

token distributions.definition: La manière dont les jetons sont répartis entre les différents groupes de parties prenantes.

token pair.definition: The two associated cryptocurrencies that make up a liquidity pool.

token pairs.definition: The two associated cryptocurrencies that make up a liquidity pool.

tps.definition: A measure of a blockchains scalability, TPS is the number of transactions per second processed by a blockchain.

tpss.definition: A measure of a blockchains scalability, TPS is the number of transactions per second processed by a blockchain.

trade.definition: Exchanging assets or money for something valuable ; money verb on the skill cube.

trades.definition: Exchanging assets or money for something valuable ; money verb on the skill cube.

trade route.definition: What is the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade.

trade routes.definition: What is the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade.

trade routing.definition: Planning the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade.

trade routings.definition: Planning the path taken from starting token to ending token in a trade.

transaction.definition: A record of transfer, monetary or otherwise, on the blockchain.

transactions.definition: A record of transfer, monetary or otherwise, on the blockchain.

transaction finality.definition: The time it takes to be sure that a transaction is valid and final, meaning it won't be reversed or changed.

transaction finalitys.definition: The time it takes to be sure that a transaction is valid and final, meaning it won't be reversed or changed.

transaction hash.definition: The unique identifier for each transaction; it is derived from the transaction data, the digital signature of the transaction sender, and a one-time use number to avoid duplicate transactions.

transaction hashs.definition: The unique identifier for each transaction; it is derived from the transaction data, the digital signature of the transaction sender, and a one-time use number to avoid duplicate transactions.

transaction throughput.definition: How many transactions a blockchain can process at once, usually measured in transactions per second (TPS).

transaction throughputs.definition: How many transactions a blockchain can process at once, usually measured in transactions per second (TPS).

sans tiers de confiance.definition: La qualité de fonctionner sans avoir besoin de faire confiance à des personnes ou à des institutions. (Automatique, n'appartenant à personne).

trustlesss.definition: La qualité de fonctionner sans avoir besoin de faire confiance à des personnes ou à des institutions. (Automatique, n'appartenant à personne).

tvl.definition: (Total Value Locked) The overall amount of asset value stored in a specific place.

tvls.definition: (Total Value Locked) The overall amount of asset value stored in a specific place.

validating bridge.definition: A validating bridge contract is a new design that removes the need to trust any external authority to decide if a withdrawal is valid.

validating bridges.definition: A validating bridge contract is a new design that removes the need to trust any external authority to decide if a withdrawal is valid.

véto.definition: Un vote de rejet d'une proposition de gouvernance.

vetos.definition: Un vote de rejet d'une proposition de gouvernance.

wallet.definition: A wallet is an application or device used to send and receive crypto assets on the blockchain.

wallets.definition: A wallet is an application or device used to send and receive crypto assets on the blockchain.

web2.definition: The current state of the internet, without blockchain infrastructure.

web2s.definition: The current state of the internet, without blockchain infrastructure.

web3.definition: Refers to the internet of blockchains, where users can self-custody their assets & data.

web3s.definition: Refers to the internet of blockchains, where users can self-custody their assets & data.

zero-knowledge.definition: Mathematical method that allows one party to prove a statement is valid without revealing any additional information about it.

zero-knowledges.definition: Mathematical method that allows one party to prove a statement is valid without revealing any additional information about it.

zk rollup.definition: A layer-2 rollup scaling solution that uses zero-knowledge proofs to guarantee the validity of “rolled up” transactions while maintaining security and privacy on the layer 1 blockchain.

zk rollups.definition: A layer-2 rollup scaling solution that uses zero-knowledge proofs to guarantee the validity of “rolled up” transactions while maintaining security and privacy on the layer 1 blockchain.
